TextDisplayValue: WARNINGWhen working with any decontaminant, take appropriate measures to avoid getting the substance into the eyes and mouth or onto the skin. In the event of eye, mouth, or skin contact, refer to the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for emergencies or first aid. WARNINGLiquids deployed by this system may be slippery. WARNINGNEVER operate the HMDS if an air line or discharge hose is worn/damaged, or if an air leak has been discovered. Once pressurized, a loose/leaking/damaged connection and/or hose may disconnect or rupture, potentially causing serious injury. WARNINGALWAYS treat the HMDS as though the discharge line(s) are pressurized. Once the system is pressurized, it will remain so until the air supply is turned off and the system is completely depressurized. A depressurized system can be identified by examining the air pressure gauge or the lack of a hissing sound. WARNINGALWAYS ensure that all connections, hoses, and nozzles are tightly attached while operating the HMDS. ALWAYS point all discharge devices in a safe direction.

TextDisplayValue: WARNINGThe HMDS engine runs on diesel fuel. Observe all applicable precautions when handling, storing, or dispensing fuels. WARNINGThe Power Unit uses a 12V DC battery to supply electrical energy to the starter. To mitigate risks associated with the battery/charging system, do not remove or install any cables while the system is running or energized. Never allow any object to touch metal components in the battery box or other electrical components. WARNINGDisconnect all battery cables before servicing the HMDS engine. WARNINGSome parts of this system, especially the exhaust system, may be hot to the touch during and after operation. NEVER attempt to service internal components while the HMDS is running! Once the system is shut down, allow adequate time for components to cool before attempting to service any internal components. WARNINGThe operator shall have a firm grip and wide stance while discharging a hose from a spray nozzle. The HMDS propels solutions with significant force! Once the system is pressurized, never release the hose prior to closing the discharge nozzle/D-bale hand set and/or the Pump Control valve. A loose discharge hose will whip around violently and can cause serious injury or equipment damage. Always close the Pump Control valve on the Power Unit's Control Panel and relieve pressure from the discharge line before releasing the hose.

TextDisplayValue: The High Mobility Decontamination System (HMDS) is a modular, diesel-driven system specifically designed for rapid, mobile decontamination missions for terrain and military equipment. The system is designed to be operated while mounted in the back of a M1083 vehicle or on a M1095 trailer, while stationary or mobile. The HMDS Power Unit uses a Diesel engine-powered air compressor to create and propel decontamination solutions through a 1.5" (3.81cm) pump. It deploys these solutions through vehicle- or trailer-mounted spray bars, a remote-control stanchion-mounted Monitor (water cannon), and non-collapsible hoses with D-Bale handset(s).  The HMDS is capable of drafting from external water sources, such as bulk tanks or natural bodies of water. In addition to the Power Unit, the HMDS incorporates two solution-mixing tanks, each with a fill capacity of 750 gallons. The tanks are constructed with internal baffles to minimize liquid movement and weight shift during transport.

TextDisplayValue: The HMDS has two 750-gallon tanks with incorporated skids. Tank Specifications:Weight (empty): ~1,000 lbs.  Weight (full of water): ~7,500 lbs.  Overall Dimensions (with skid, without storage basket): 92" L x 80" W x 43.5" H Actual Dimensions of the Tank (outside-to-outside): 68" L x 78" W x 36" H   The tanks are built using a 4-way, modular platform skid design which allows for 360-degree forklifting capability. EMPTY tanks can also be lifted from underneath with a forklift, using extended forks or slings and an overhead crane or wrecker. They can be loaded from either the rear or the sides of transport vehicles.  Both tanks have an approximate 13" notched bottom lip (skid cutouts to the front to accommodate the monitor) on the front ends, which butts the tank against the front wall of the truck bed. This helps in preventing slippage and damage to the tank itself.  Each tank is equipped with a Hopper/Blender assembly and fill connection, Agitator assembly and fill connection, tank level indicator port, and a ball valve fluid output/drain with a 1.5" camlock. WARNING! Although the tanks are sturdy and supported with internal baffles, do not stand on them! They may become very slippery and can create a slip and fall hazard.

TextDisplayValue: The stainless steel Hopper/Blender is used to aid in mixing powdered, liquid, and granular decontaminant materials into a tank. It has a 16" diameter and the funnel section is 22" deep. It has a plastic lid, which is attached by a lanyard, and a removable stainless steel screen. The screen has a handle on top and several 1" diameter holes across its surface. The holes assist with breaking up clumps of powdered or granular decontaminant that could clog the 1.5" diameter funnel output spout.  The Hopper/Blender is primarily fed by a 1.5" EZLink camlock fitting on the White Banded Hopper Hose. Alternatively, it can be fed by the Red Banded Discharge Hoses, or any other 1.5" diameter hose in the HMDS hose kit. The Hopper/Blender is located next to the Agitator and has two (2) 1/2" stainless steel bars in the funnel section. These bars support the removable screen and help prevent objects from accidentally falling into the tank. If there are ?clumps? of decontaminant on the bars or screen, use a disposable dipstick made of wood or plastic (supplied by the unit) to break them down to a size which will allow the clumps to feed through the screen.  WARNING! DO NOT use a hammer, metal objects, or excessive force that could cause damage to the Hopper.  If ?clumps? are not easily breakable, simply remove them from the Hopper. WARNING! Avoid sticking fingers or gloved hands into the screen holes, as this may result in serious cuts.

TextDisplayValue: The Tank Level Inspection Port is a capped, 2" diameter port located next to the Hopper/Blender. The plastic cap is secured with a metal ?dog tag chain? lanyard. This port contains a measuring tape which is marked in 100 gallon increments on its back side. This enables visual measurement of the amount of liquid in the tank. 1" of tape represents approximately 20 gallons of liquid.  To measure the fluid level, gently pull upwards on the tape until a ?catch? is felt. Then, read the measurement.  To secure the tape, gently push it back down into the tube and re-cap the port.  The tape may also be left out of the port to watch the tank level rise or fall.

TextDisplayValue: The 750-gallon tanks must always be mounted on either a M1083 truck or M1095 trailer.  For truck-mounted tanks, the hose attachments must be pointed toward the rear of the truck. The tanks must always be mounted as far forward in the truck bed (touching the front wall) as possible. There are cutouts in the forward ends of the tank platform that incorporate room for the stanchion. For trailer-mounted tanks, the hose attachments may be oriented toward the rear or front of the trailer. The tank should be mounted over the axles and slightly forward of the center of gravity on the trailer. There are six (6) plastic guides welded to the top of the tank to indicate proper positioning of tie-down ratchet straps. Each ratchet strap is rated at 10,000 lbs. burst strength (working load limit, WLL ~3,333 lbs), and three (3) straps are required to hold the tank down to the bed of the truck or trailer. The tank must be mounted with the front (notched) portion of the lip butted up against the front wall of the truck bed to reduce shift.

TextDisplayValue: The Monitor is a water cannon used for large area/long distance decontamination. It can be configured to operate either manually or with the wired Remote-Control Box. There are 2 manual- control hand wheel knobs on the Monitor that can be used to move it if there is no power being supplied. It is made of stainless steel and is fed by the 17' long, 1.5" diameter, Purple Banded hose via an EZLink connector.  The Monitor is comprised of three (3) major components: the Monitor head, a ?haloed? Stanchion to protect the Monitor head, and a wired Remote-Control Box.  Selector Valve #2 on the Power Unit has two functions related to the Monitor:  Monitor: This setting allows liquid to flow to the Monitor constantly once the Pump Control Valve is opened.  Remote Monitor: This setting causes the flow of water to be controlled by the wired Remote-Control Box. Liquid will begin to flow to the Monitor when the switch on the controller is engaged, and will immediately stop when the switch is released. The nozzle control switch (?Fog/Stream?) controls the ?blabber? actuator on the Stream & Fog nozzle; the ?stream? is a straight flow of liquid, whereas the ?fog? is of lower pressure, and fan shaped.

TextDisplayValue: The Front Spray Bar (FSB) is used to disperse fluid from the front of a truck. It is made of stainless steel and is fed by the 1" diameter Green Banded hose. The middle section is 98" long and comes equipped with mounting brackets, as well as two capped ends that are used to attach the right- and left- ?wings.?  The mounting brackets are set up to mount the FSB to armored M1083 trucks. The bracket must be inverted in order to mount the FSB to the unarmored versions of the M1083 trucks. Two (2) 1" diameter clevis pins are used to hold the brackets onto the clevis fittings on the front of the truck.  Without the extension wings, the FSB will cover approximately 16' (wide). Ensure that the caps with gaskets are in place and locked down. Failure to do so will result in liquid spraying up the side(s) of the truck.  The right- and left-wings extend the FSB?s overall length by 4' each (8' overall), for a total spray pattern that is approximately 32' wide. The right wing is marked with an ?R? and red bands, while the left wing is marked with an ?L? and green bands. To avoid damaging the FSB or the vehicle, each wing can swivel backwards if it strikes an object.  To add the wings to the FSB, detach the camlock caps on each end of the middle section. Then, attach the wings using the Instalock fittings. Make certain that there is a rubber gasket in the fitting or the FSB won?t operate properly.  The center nozzles on the middle spray bar and the inner nozzles on the wings point approximately 45 degrees forward from the vertical. The outer nozzles on the wings point outward and downward.

The brackets are equipped with 1" diameter clevis pins to fasten the RSB brackets to the rear clevis fixtures on the truck or the trailer. When mounted on the back of a truck, the RSB can be fed by a single 1" diameter Orange Banded hose. However, when the RSB is mounted to the back of a trailer, both Orange Banded hoses must be connected using a 1" male-male adapter in order to reach the Power Unit. The central nozzles on the RSB point downward (near vertical) and the outer nozzles point outward from the sides. There is a bolt on the bottom of each of the two RSB brackets that the operator can use to adjust the angle of the RSB. TextDisplayValue: The HMDS Power Unit uses a 5-gallon ?jerry? can Fuel Container. It is seated in a holder on the side of the Power Unit and must be secured by the strap before system operation and/or transport.  The fuel container also uses a fuel line/cap that includes a fuel level indicator. ?F? denotes full, ?E? denotes empty. There is a check valve at the bottom of the siphon tube on the fuel cap system. It will help reduce the loss of fuel prime to the engine, making startups after storage or transportation easier. WARNING!Avoid allowing the fuel level to fall below ? tank. The Power Unit will shut down without fuel, which may cause damage to the fuel system. Running the fuel rail or filters dry will eventually damage the fuel pump and fuel injectors. TextDisplayValue: Secure the tank to the bed of the truck or trailer in the following manner. Refer to the diagram for the authorized tie down procedure. Three (3) 10,000 lb. cargo tie-down ratchet straps are used on the tank and passed over the tank at the guides, welded to the top of the tank.  The guides correspond to D-Rings on the truck/trailer bed.  The tank?s notched front lip must be butted up against the front wall of the truck/trailer bed; the lip prevents the tank from shifting forward in a sudden braking event.   Attach the free, hooked end of the strap on the driver?s side and run the straps over the guides and under the storage basket to secure. Attach the ratchet end of the strap on the passenger side of the vehicle or trailer.  Check each strap for tightness as part of the system's daily PMCS.   WARNING! Always follow the manufacturer?s instructions on how to securely restrain all HMDS components to the transport platform before transportation of any kind. Failure to do so may result in damage to equipment, injury, or death!

TextDisplayValue: The 8' long Spray Bars are designed to be universally fit-enabled by an adjustable slide bracket mechanism. This allows for up to 2? of lateral adjustability during installation. This mechanism also allows for interchangeability between the Front Spray Bar (FSB) mounts on the M1083 variants. The spray bars are held in place with the clevis pins on the shackle mounts. The spray bars themselves are designed with four (4) ?", 80-degree fan spray tips. Each tip produces ~60 psi of pressure. The FSB also has attachable ?wings? or outriggers to extend the spraying pattern wider (up to 32' wide) using a total of 8 fan spray tips/nozzles. The Rear Spray Bar (RSB) is also a universal fit. It can be mounted on the rear of the M1083 FMTV style trucks and the M1095 series trailers.  WARNING! NEVER stand on the spray bars. Doing so may cause injury and/or system damage.

TextDisplayValue: There are 2 different universal spray bar mounts. The one pictured with the SHORT extension will ALWAYS be mounted on the FRONT of the truck ONLY. The second, pictured below the first, with the LONG extension will be mounted on the REAR of either the truck or trailer.  The slide is designed to keep the spray bar from rolling down and must be butted against the trailer by the locked down slide to keep it from doing so. The slide will be retracted and tightened down for placement on the rear of the truck. The slide will be extended and locked down for placement on the trailer. Ensure the slide bolt is tight. Check periodically and re-tighten if rolling starts to occur. Non-armored vehicles may require the installer to disassemble and invert the truck side of the adjustable slide bracket. The Front Spray Bar (FSB) is equipped with two capped ends that enable the attachment of extensions, sometimes called ?outriggers? or ?wings?, to provide a significantly wider spray pattern. The wings are marked with red markings and an "R" on the right side, and green markings and an "L" on the left side.  The orientation of the nozzles on the wings are important for correct function of the spray bars; the slots should be in line with the long axis of the bars. Attach the wings using the Instalock camlock fittings and ensure there is a rubber gasket in each of them for correct sealing and seating. Each wing will swivel rearward if it strikes a fixed item while the vehicle is moving. The gasket may need to be replaced often due to wear on the part.

TextDisplayValue: To install the Monitor/StanchionRemove the selected davit pocket cover by removing the pin and then pull the cover down through the davit pocket. It is attached with a wire lanyard to the truck to prevent loss.Insert the Monitor/Stanchion into the davit pocket.Reinsert the pin to secure the Monitor/Stanchion. The Stanchion can be mounted in any one of the four (4) davit pockets on the M1083 truck bed. It can be placed in the davit in any position desired. Ensure that the pin for the davit pocket is used for the Stanchion. Position the Monitor?s tank input to point towards the Power Unit to avoid kinks in the hose. The ?halo? on the top of the Stanchion serves to protect and act as a lifting handle for the Monitor. The Monitor can be operated either manually or by the wired Remote-Control Box. TextDisplayValue: The Selector Valves govern individual system functions. To operate each selector knob, PUSH the selector knob IN, SELECT the operation, and RELEASE the selector knob. Prior to starting the system, ensure that the selector valves are in the OFF position and return the selector valves to the OFF position when the operation is complete. Selector 1OFF ? Stops all pump functions to Selector 1 operations.LINE 1 ? Sends fluid from the tank to the Line 1 Discharge port for hose spraying operation.AGITATOR ? Controls continuous agitation of tank contents to keep chemicals from settling.FRONT SPRAY BAR ? Supplies fluid to the Front Spray Bar.AUX 1 ? Not used.DRAFT ? Used to draw water from a source to fill tank(s). The only active discharge port is the Draft Output port on the back of the Power Unit.

TextDisplayValue: The tank(s) may be filled by a hose through the Hopper/Blender or straight into the tank. During filling operations, monitor the water level at all times by looking in the Hopper/Blender hole or at the fluid tank level indicator (measuring tape).  Use clean water when possible. If you are drafting from a natural water source, such as a stream, pond, or lake, you MUST use the Filter Basket and a bucket to ensure that particles and/or debris are not drafted into the system. These materials can clog lines and damage the pump. There are two (2) methods of filling the holding tanks: Draft Fill and Hydrant Fill.

TextDisplayValue: Using the HMDS, water can be transferred from one "holding" tank to another "recipient" tank. This is called a Tank-to-Tank Operation. In the example below, water will be drawn from the "holding" trailer tank to fill the "recipient" truck tank. Turn the Air Control valve and Pump Control valve to the full OFF position.Ensure that the trailer tank is filled with water.Use the White Banded hose to connect the Hopper/Blender on the truck tank to the Discharge Line #2 port on the front of the Power Unit. Alternatively, use the Purple Banded hose to connect the Hopper/Blender on the truck tank to the Monitor output port on the back of the Power Unit.Attach the Tank Selector valve to the Fluid Input port on the back of the Power Unit.Use the short Black Banded hose to connect the Fluid In/Drain valve on the truck tank to the short connector on the Tank Selector valve.Use the long, Double Black Banded hose to connect the Fluid In/Drain valve of the trailer tank to the long connector on the Tank Selector valve.Turn the Tank Selector valve handle to the trailer tank position. Start the Power Unit.Depending on the port being used, set Selector Valve 2 to the "LINE 2" or "MONITOR" setting.SLOWLY turn the Pump Control valve to the full ON position to begin filling the truck tank.Allow the system to run until the desired amount of water is in the the truck tank.SLOWLY turn the Pump Control valve to the full OFF position.Set Selector Valve 2 to the OFF position.Shut down the Power Unit.

TextDisplayValue: WARNING!Please note that antifreeze should NEVER be used with Super Tropical Bleach. The reaction between these materials will release a significant amount of heat or flames that may damage the system.   WARNING! Always wear proper PPE when dispensing decontaminate.  CAUTION: The Agitator and the Hopper/Blender hoses will contain slurry. Rinse and clean out the tanks, hoses, and any fittings thoroughly before properly storing them. CAUTION: You can still operate the Hopper/Blender, but it may introduce more air in the slurry mixture and cause foaming after mixing. CAUTION: The Agitator and the Hopper/Blender hoses will contain slurry. Rinse and clean out these hoses and any fittings thoroughly before storing them in the tank basket. CAUTION: After the slurry is blended, it must be agitated constantly until used. It is useful to agitate with both the Agitator and the Hopper/Blender. Use the ?Agitator? function on Selector Valve #1 and ?Monitor? on Selector Valve #2. Then, route the Monitor hose (Purple Band) or a short discharge hose (Double Red Band) to the Hopper/Blender. The alternate is to use the #2 Discharge port to the Hopper/Blender with a Double Red Banded hose. Decide which method you will use in advance, as to avoid changing over hoses and connections. After blending is complete, replace the tank lid. Agitate the slurry mixture and avoid adding air with the Agitator to reduce foaming.

TextDisplayValue: Slurry is a non-expanded, highly concentrated solution that is applied in a semi-liquid consistency. Slurry can be applied to surfaces such as roads, airfields, parking aprons, pier sides, and taxiways. It is used primarily for terrain decontamination. NOTE:Contact Unit Maintenance prior to mixing slurry, as you will need to temporarily replace the Air Check valve with a ?" NPT galvanized iron plug (located in the storage case). The Air Check valve is located inside the Power Unit, on top of the pump module, underneath the Battery Box. Use Teflon sealing paste (e.g., Blue Monster) or Teflon tape to aid in sealing the plug and making removal easier at the end of the mission. It is not necessary to remove the Air Check valve, let it hang free with the air tubing still attached. Simply turn off the Air Control valve on the control panel as you will not need to add air to make certain types of slurry. Replace the plug with the Air Check valve after the Mission is completed and after flushing out the entire Power Unit with clear water.

TextDisplayValue: The primary slurry mixing configuration is conducted by a Power Unit and main tank with a secondary tank filled with rinse/source water. Two Tanks (Truck and Trailer)  The Two-Tank configuration uses both of the 750-Gallon tanks for the slurry mixing operation. The main (truck) tank is used to mix the slurry and the trailer tank is a source of water for mixing and rinsing the truck tank. The availability of rinse water is necessary to help clear any clogged lines and to rapidly flush out the system after discharging the slurry.   Using the Tank Selector Valve attached to the rear of the Power Unit, attach the Suction Main (Single Black Band) hose to the left side of the Tank Selector Valve and the Trailer Suction hose (Double Black Band) to the right side. Then, connect each hose to the appropriate tank and open up the Tank Drain Valves. Connect the White Banded Hopper/Blender hose to the Hopper/Blender on the truck tank and connect the other end to the Monitor port on the back of the Power Unit. Next, connect the Single Yellow Banded Agitator hose to the Agitator port on the truck tank and connect the other end to the Agitator Port on the back side of the Power Unit.  To fill the main truck tank with water, turn the Tank Selector Valve to ?Trailer?. Once the fluid level is sufficient for your Mission/slurry batch size (verified with the tank level Indicator) turn the Tank Selector Valve to draw from the main truck tank.

TextDisplayValue: Single TankWhen using only the truck tank to mix slurry, the unit will need to supply water for mixing from an external source, such as a blivet, drop tank, tank/pump unit, hydrant, or natural source. Make the mixing connections the same way as for the truck tank configuration, but the system will draft water vertically or horizontally to fill water into the mixing tank.  Keep in mind that you cannot perform any other functions (i.e., agitation, mixing with the Monitor/discharge outlets) while drafting in through the drafting port and out through the draft outlet port.  Use the Vertical Draft hose (Single Blue Band) to draw water from sources below the level of the truck tires up to the Power Unit and into the main (truck) tank.  Use the Horizontal Drafting hose (Double Blue Bands) to draw water horizontally from a drop tank or blivet (Same elevation or level as the truck tires).  NOTE: To extend the horizontal drafting distance, connect the Suction Trailer (Double Black Bands) hose using the 1.5" x 1.5" male-to-male connector to the Horizontal Drafting hose. Using this method, drafting time may increase.

TextDisplayValue: Agitating Slurry in the TankAgitate slurry when the solution is not being dispersed or is only being dispersed from a single output source. Make sure the Agitator hose (Yellow Band) is connected to the Agitator port on the back of the Power Unit and that Selector Valve #1 is set to the "Agitator" function.  Continue to agitate while dispensing the slurry. Once the slurry is dispensed (approx. 15-30 minutes for a standard batch), rinse and flush the tank immediately or immediately make another batch. NOTE:Agitation can be stopped to conduct your Mission when two dispersal sources are required, such as FSB/RSB operation, FSB or RSB /Monitor operation, two (2) D-Bales, or any combination of two (2) outputs.

TextDisplayValue: FSB/RSB (Spray Bars)The system can disperse slurry from both the FSB/RSB, as long as the solution does not need to be actively agitated. NOTE:If the solution is going to sit for longer than approximately 10 minutes, it should be agitated.  D-BaleIf dispersing slurry with a gun, use Discharge #2 and a D-Bale gun with the shaper tip nozzle or the Monitor outlet (on the back of the Power Unit) using the Remote Monitor function on Selector Valve #2. After the spraying Mission is complete, flush, drain, clean, and store the apparatus according to procedure outlined in the ?Operating the HMDS? lesson.

TextDisplayValue: Tank Cleaning ProcedureUse proper PPE when cleaning tanks.Drain the tank of all fluid by opening the drain and routing liquid away with a hose.Pre-rinse the inside and the outside of the tank with water.Using the discharge hoses and guns, wash the tank with a liquid detergent (i.e. ?Dawn? dish soap) and water solution. Use the inspection/clean out ports to reach inside the tank.Flush the tank with clean water.Dispose of all wastewater appropriately, according to which chemicals were used.Repeat this procedure until the tank is thoroughly cleaned. Any residual chemicals may harden and cause a clog. Special techniques to clear clogs or to remove decontaminant residue from the tanks include: Use a ?? to ?? shaper tip nozzle to shoot water into clogs/residue.A pressure washer may be required to assist with cleaning off large amounts of decontaminant.Agitate the tank using clean water when flushing the tank. Add air to the Agitator to clear clogs.If the Main Tank Drain Valve becomes clogged, back flush the Main Tank Drain Valve using a 1.5? hose and any of the 1.5? discharge functions.With the Hopper/Blender removed, shovel out any large chunks of decontaminant and dispose of them per unit environmental procedures.

TextDisplayValue: While storing the HMDS in environments with temperatures below 32? F, it is possible that the Power Unit?s pump may crack if residual water freezes within the pump housing. TextDisplayValue: Internal Safety Systems The Power Unit is designed with various safety controls. If any of the Red LED Engine lights located to the left of the PLC illuminate, the unit is designed to automatically shutdown on its own. This also signals that the Power Unit started to run outside one or several of the programmed operating ranges.  If the following unit-level troubleshooting methods do not resolve the issue, STOP and always contact maintenance support. Continued use of the Power Unit could cause severe damage to the system's components.  The Programmable Logic Control (PLC) navigation button allows for scrolling to obtain specific engine operational data which monitors the safety cut-off features. These parameters must be set and adjusted only by qualified service technicians. WARNING!The following Trouble Shooting-Corrective Actions are considered Maintainer level tasks. The Maintainer may not have access to this information. Please disseminate this information accordingly.

TextDisplayValue: Corrective ActionsClean and/or tighten the battery terminals. Test the battery. Charge the battery. Replace the battery, if required. Check the fuel gauge to ensure the can is not empty. Refill/replace with clean fuel, if required.Check the fuel pickup for obstructions. If air can?t flow through the lines, neither can fuel. Check the fuel line connections on the back of the Power Unit. If contaminated fuel is suspected, change the fuel supply and empty the water/fuel separator. Shut the system down and allow the system to cool. DO NOT check oil levels until the oil has had time to drain back into the pan. Verify the oil drain valve is in the closed position. Note the last time the oil and oil filter were changed and change them, if required. While the system is shutdown, check the wiring to and from the indicator light. Verify there are no loose connections and blow out any excess moisture. Shut the system down and allow it to cool. DO NOT attempt to check/add coolant until the system has cooled down and coolant has drained back to the reservoirs. Once the system is  cool, open the radiator cap to verify coolant levels. Add fluid to the cooling tank, as required. Inspect the coolant reservoir and ensure the coolant is at the proper level. While the system is shutdown, check the air filter. Clean or replace the filter, if required. Ensure the system has sufficient air flow to and around the unit. Once the system is restarted, observe the cooling fan to ensure it is engaging (coming on) to cool the system. If not, you could have a belt problem. Fuel flow can be restricted/interrupted in numerous ways. Check the fuel supply, and replace if required. Verify that the pickup is not clogged. Check the fuel line connections from the supply to the HMDS. Note the last time the fuel filter was changed and replace it, if required. Check the fuel/water separator and drain it, if required. Shut the system down and allow the system to cool. DO NOT attempt to check or add compressor oil until the system has had time to drain the oil back into the reservoirs. Once the system is cool, check the compressor oil level and add oil, as necessary.

TextDisplayValue: Corrective ActionsAdd water to the water tank. The unit can continue to operate while water is added through top-fill port. Shut down the Power Unit. Completely dry the internals of the system and wipe up any fluid puddles. When these actions are complete, restart the system and cycle through the fluid drafting and fluid discharge modes. After each is performed, shut down the system and check for leaks. If leaks are confirmed, inspect the suspected source. Contact Maintenance Support for replacement parts, if necessary. If due to a loose connection, tighten the connection.  Park on a level surface and completely fill the tank(s) with water. Wipe up any fluid on the tank/areas suspected of leaking. If possible, use compressed air to blow the area dry. Wait several hours and reinspect the suspected source of the leak. If the fluid storage tank is damaged/compromised, contact Maintenance Support. When spraying liquid only, ensure the Air Control valve is turned to the ?Full Wet? setting

TextDisplayValue: Corrective ActionsVerify that all connections are properly made and that all valves/dials are in the proper position. Inspect the drafting hose for cuts or tears. Ensure the sealing washer on the system connector is present, clean, and undamaged. Inspect the draft hose filter and ensure the ball moves freely when you tip the valve. Ensure the filter is fully submerged in the liquid source.  Shut down the Power Unit. Completely dry the internals of the system and wipe up any fluid puddles. When these actions are complete, restart the system and cycle through the fluid drafting and fluid discharge modes. After each is performed, shut down the system and check for leaks. If leaks are confirmed, inspect the suspected source. Contact Maintenance Support for replacement parts, if necessary. If due to a loose connection, tighten the connection.

TextDisplayValue: Corrective ActionsVerify that all connections are properly made and that all valves/dials are in the proper position. Inspect the drafting hose for cuts or tears. Ensure the sealing washer on the system connector is present, clean, and undamaged. Inspect the draft hose filter and ensure the ball moves freely when you tip the valve. If the problem persists in different conditions, contact Maintenance Support for service.
